questions.explanation: The intersection $A \cap B$ contains exactly the elements common to both sets. Only $3$ is in both.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct definition of the set difference $B \setminus A$?
questions.explanation: By definition, $B \setminus A$ consists of elements that are inside $B$ but outside $A$.

questions.text: Which of the following statements involving the empty set $\emptyset$ is FALSE?
questions.explanation: The empty set is a subset of every set (so A and B are true). It is an element only if explicitly listed inside the braces (like in C). It is NOT an element of $\{1, 2, 3\}$.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the union $A \cup B$?
questions.explanation: The union contains all elements that belong to $A$, to $B$, or to both. In logic, 'or' is inclusive.

questions.text: Let $A=\{1,2,3\}$. Let $\mathcal{P}(A)$ be the power set of $A$: the collection of subsets of $A$. How many elements does this have?
questions.explanation: There are $2^3=8$ possible subsets, since for each of the three elements $1,2,3$, a subset either contains it or does not.

questions.text: Which logical statement defines that a function $f: X \to Y$ is surjective (onto)?
choices: $\forall y \in Y, \exists x \in X \text{ such that } f(x)=y$
$\exists y \in Y \text{ such that } \forall x \in X, f(x) \neq y$
$\forall x \in X, \exists y \in Y \text{ such that } f(x)=y$
questions.explanation: Surjective means every element $y$ in the codomain $B$ is 'hit' by at least one arrow from $A$.

questions.text: Which statement is the formal definition of injective (one-to-one)?
choices: $\forall y \in Y, \exists x \in X \text{ such that } f(x)=y$
$\exists y \in Y \text{ such that } \forall x \in X, f(x) \neq y$
$\forall x \in X, \exists y \in Y \text{ such that } f(x)=y$
questions.explanation: Injectivity means that if the outputs are equal, the inputs MUST have been equal. In diagrams, no two arrows hit the same point.

questions.text: Let $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ be defined by $f(x)=x^2$. Which statement is true?
questions.explanation:
• Not injective: $f(-1) = f(1) = 1$.
• Not surjective: Negative numbers (like $-1$) are not in the range of $x^2$.

questions.text: Which of the following functions $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ is injective?
questions.explanation:
• $x^2, |x|, \sin(x)$ all map multiple inputs to the same output (e.g., $\sin(0)=\sin(\pi)$).
• $x^3$ is strictly increasing, so distinct inputs always go to distinct outputs.

questions.text: Let $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ be $f(x) = x^2$. What is the inverse image $f^{-1}([4, 9])$?
questions.explanation: We need all $x$ such that $4 \le x^2 \le 9$. This happens when $2 \le x \le 3$ OR when $-3 \le x \le -2$.

questions.text:
Let $A = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}$ and $B = \{10, 20, 30\}$.
Define the function $f: A \to B$ by the mapping: $f(1)=10, f(2)=10, f(3)=20, f(4)=20$.
What is the image (or range, NL: beeld) of $f$?
questions.explanation: The codomain is all of $B$ ($\{10, 20, 30\}$), but the image contains only the elements that are actually 'hit' by the function. Since no input maps to $30$, the image is just $\{10, 20\}$.
